Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 28, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 385 of 1959.

This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the order of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh reversing, on State appeal, the order of the Additional Sessions judge, Hoshangabad, acquiring the appellant,

and convicting him of an offence under s. 414 I. P.C. Five bales, containing woollen shawls and mufflers despatched from Kanpur by the British India Corporation Ltd., Kanpur Woollen Mills Branch, Kanpur,

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for voluntarily assisting in concealing or disposing of stolen property

the appeal against Ajendra Nath for the offence of conspiracy. It however allowed the appeal against Ajendra Nath with respect to the offence under s. 414 I.P.C.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for voluntarily assisting in concealing or disposing of stolen property

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was also urged that even if the identity of the articles recovered with the articles stolen be established, no offence under s.414 I.P.C. is made out against the appellant as the other accused have been acquitted and it is not known whom the appellant is supposed to have helped in concealing the stolen property. Section 414 I.P.C. makes it an offence for a person to assist voluntarily in concealing or disposing of or making away with property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property. It is not necessary for a person to be convicted under s.414 I.P.C. that another person must be traced out and convicted of an offence of committing theft. The prosecution has simply to establish that the property recovered is stolen property and that the appellant provided help in its concealment and disposal.

concepts.interpretation: Section 414 IPC punishes voluntary assistance in concealing, disposing, or making away with stolen property if the person knows or has reason to believe it is stolen. Conviction under this section does not require tracing or convicting the principal thief; it suffices to prove the property is stolen and the accused assisted in its concealment/disposal.

issues.text: Whether the appellant assisted voluntarily in concealing or disposing of the stolen property knowing or having reason to believe it to be stolen

anchor.surface_text: Section 414 I.P.C. makes it an offence for a person to assist voluntarily in stealing or disposing of or making away with property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property. It is number necessary for a person to be companyvicted under s.414 I.P.C. that another person must be traced out and companyvicted of an offence of companymitting theft. The prosecution has simply to establish that the property recovered is stolen property and that the appellant provided help in its companycealment and disposal. The circumstances of the recovery sufficiently make out that the property was deliberately divided into different packets and was separately kept.

arguments.claim: s.414 IPC does not require conviction of thief for accused's conviction

anchor.surface_text: Section 414 I.P.C. makes it an offence for a person to assist voluntarily in concealing or disposing of or making away with property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property. It is number necessary for a person to be convicted under s.414 I.P.C. that another person must be traced out and convicted of an offence of committing theft.

holdings.text: the finding that these shawls and mufflers were the manufacture of Kanpur Woollen Mills is correct

anchor.surface_text: We therefore consider that the finding that these shawls and mufflers were the manufacture of Kanpur Woollen Mills is correct. It was also contended for the appellant that it was not proved that these shawls and mufflers were in the bales which were despatched by the Kanpur Woollen Mills and that the gate passes and the invoices produced by Kunzru were not proved as persons who wrote them had not been examined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Silk and paper labels indicate manufacture; no suggestion labels were deceptive

holdings.text: no good reason for considering the finding of the High Court with respect to the bed-sheets recovered to be stolen property to be wrong

anchor.surface_text: We therefore see no good reason for considering the finding of the High Court with respect to the bed-sheets recovered to be stolen property to be wrong. It was also contended that it was not open to the High Court to record a finding about the recovered property to be stolen property when the Government had not appealed against the other accused who were acquitted on the basis of the finding that the property recovered was not proved to be stolen property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witnesses recognized own handwriting on labels; no suggestion police fabricated markings

holdings.text: We do not see any force in this contention

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any force in this contention. The mere fact that the learned Additional Sessions judge acquitted the other accused on the ground that the property recovered was not proved to be stolen property did not preclude the State from appealing against the acquittal of the appellant against whom there is better evidence for establishing that he was in possession of the stolen property than the evidence was against the other accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State can appeal acquittal of appellant specifically; High Court can reassess evidence against him

It is not necessary for a person to be convicted under s.414 I.P.C. that another person must be traced out and convicted of an offence of committing theft. The prosecution has simply to establish that the property recovered is stolen property and that the appellant provided help in its concealment and disposal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.414 requires only proof of stolen property and voluntary assistance, not conviction of thief
